documentation:
AWS Glue

Defines the public endpoint for the AWS Glue service.

BatchCreatePartition.documentation: Creates one or more partitions in a batch operation.
BatchCreatePartition.name: BatchCreatePartition

BatchDeleteConnection.documentation: Deletes a list of connection definitions from the Data Catalog.
BatchDeleteConnection.name: BatchDeleteConnection

BatchDeletePartition.documentation: Deletes one or more partitions in a batch operation.
BatchDeletePartition.name: BatchDeletePartition

BatchDeleteTable.documentation:
Deletes multiple tables at once.

After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the table versions and partitions that belong to the deleted table. AWS Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.

To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling BatchDeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.
BatchDeleteTable.name: BatchDeleteTable

BatchDeleteTableVersion.documentation: Deletes a specified batch of versions of a table.
BatchDeleteTableVersion.name: BatchDeleteTableVersion

BatchGetCrawlers.documentation: Returns a list of resource metadata for a given list of crawler names. After calling the ListCrawlers operation, you can call this operation to access the data to which you have been granted permissions. This operation supports all IAM permissions, including permission conditions that uses tags.
BatchGetCrawlers.name: BatchGetCrawlers

BatchGetDevEndpoints.documentation: Returns a list of resource metadata for a given list of development endpoint names. After calling the ListDevEndpoints operation, you can call this operation to access the data to which you have been granted permissions. This operation supports all IAM permissions, including permission conditions that uses tags.
BatchGetDevEndpoints.name: BatchGetDevEndpoints

BatchGetJobs.documentation: Returns a list of resource metadata for a given list of job names. After calling the ListJobs operation, you can call this operation to access the data to which you have been granted permissions. This operation supports all IAM permissions, including permission conditions that uses tags.
BatchGetJobs.name: BatchGetJobs

BatchGetTriggers.documentation: Returns a list of resource metadata for a given list of trigger names. After calling the ListTriggers operation, you can call this operation to access the data to which you have been granted permissions. This operation supports all IAM permissions, including permission conditions that uses tags.
BatchGetTriggers.name: BatchGetTriggers

BatchGetWorkflows.documentation: Returns a list of resource metadata for a given list of workflow names. After calling the ListWorkflows operation, you can call this operation to access the data to which you have been granted permissions. This operation supports all IAM permissions, including permission conditions that uses tags.
BatchGetWorkflows.name: BatchGetWorkflows

BatchStopJobRun.documentation: Stops one or more job runs for a specified job definition.
BatchStopJobRun.name: BatchStopJobRun

CancelMLTaskRun.documentation: Cancels (stops) a task run. Machine learning task runs are asynchronous tasks that AWS Glue runs on your behalf as part of various machine learning workflows. You can cancel a machine learning task run at any time by calling CancelMLTaskRun with a task run's parent transform's TransformID and the task run's TaskRunId.
CancelMLTaskRun.name: CancelMLTaskRun

CreateClassifier.documentation: Creates a classifier in the user's account. This can be a GrokClassifier, an XMLClassifier, a JsonClassifier, or a CsvClassifier, depending on which field of the request is present.
CreateClassifier.name: CreateClassifier

CreateConnection.documentation: Creates a connection definition in the Data Catalog.
CreateConnection.name: CreateConnection

CreateCrawler.documentation: Creates a new crawler with specified targets, role, configuration, and optional schedule. At least one crawl target must be specified, in the s3Targets field, the jdbcTargets field, or the DynamoDBTargets field.
CreateCrawler.name: CreateCrawler

CreateDatabase.documentation: Creates a new database in a Data Catalog.
CreateDatabase.name: CreateDatabase

CreateMLTransform.documentation:
Creates an AWS Glue machine learning transform. This operation creates the transform and all the necessary parameters to train it.

Call this operation as the first step in the process of using a machine learning transform (such as the FindMatches transform) for deduplicating data. You can provide an optional Description, in addition to the parameters that you want to use for your algorithm.

You must also specify certain parameters for the tasks that AWS Glue runs on your behalf as part of learning from your data and creating a high-quality machine learning transform. These parameters include Role, and optionally, AllocatedCapacity, Timeout, and MaxRetries. For more information, see Jobs.
CreateMLTransform.name: CreateMLTransform

CreateScript.documentation: Transforms a directed acyclic graph (DAG) into code.
CreateScript.name: CreateScript

CreateSecurityConfiguration.documentation: Creates a new security configuration. A security configuration is a set of security properties that can be used by AWS Glue. You can use a security configuration to encrypt data at rest. For information about using security configurations in AWS Glue, see Encrypting Data Written by Crawlers, Jobs, and Development Endpoints.
CreateSecurityConfiguration.name: CreateSecurityConfiguration

CreateTable.documentation: Creates a new table definition in the Data Catalog.
CreateTable.name: CreateTable

CreateUserDefinedFunction.documentation: Creates a new function definition in the Data Catalog.
CreateUserDefinedFunction.name: CreateUserDefinedFunction

DeleteClassifier.documentation: Removes a classifier from the Data Catalog.
DeleteClassifier.name: DeleteClassifier

DeleteConnection.documentation: Deletes a connection from the Data Catalog.
DeleteConnection.name: DeleteConnection

DeleteCrawler.documentation: Removes a specified crawler from the AWS Glue Data Catalog, unless the crawler state is RUNNING.
DeleteCrawler.name: DeleteCrawler

DeleteDatabase.documentation:
Removes a specified database from a Data Catalog.

After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the tables (and all table versions and partitions that might belong to the tables) and the user-defined functions in the deleted database. AWS Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.

To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling DeleteDatabase, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, DeleteUserDefinedFunction, and DeleteTable or BatchDeleteTable, to delete any resources that belong to the database.
DeleteDatabase.name: DeleteDatabase

DeleteJob.documentation: Deletes a specified job definition. If the job definition is not found, no exception is thrown.
DeleteJob.name: DeleteJob

DeleteMLTransform.documentation: Deletes an AWS Glue machine learning transform. Machine learning transforms are a special type of transform that use machine learning to learn the details of the transformation to be performed by learning from examples provided by humans. These transformations are then saved by AWS Glue. If you no longer need a transform, you can delete it by calling DeleteMLTransforms. However, any AWS Glue jobs that still reference the deleted transform will no longer succeed.
DeleteMLTransform.name: DeleteMLTransform

DeleteTable.documentation:
Removes a table definition from the Data Catalog.

After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the table versions and partitions that belong to the deleted table. AWS Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.

To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling DeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.
DeleteTable.name: DeleteTable

DeleteTableVersion.documentation: Deletes a specified version of a table.
DeleteTableVersion.name: DeleteTableVersion

DeleteTrigger.documentation: Deletes a specified trigger. If the trigger is not found, no exception is thrown.
DeleteTrigger.name: DeleteTrigger

DeleteUserDefinedFunction.documentation: Deletes an existing function definition from the Data Catalog.
DeleteUserDefinedFunction.name: DeleteUserDefinedFunction

GetCatalogImportStatus.documentation: Retrieves the status of a migration operation.
GetCatalogImportStatus.name: GetCatalogImportStatus

GetClassifiers.documentation: Lists all classifier objects in the Data Catalog.
GetClassifiers.name: GetClassifiers

GetConnection.documentation: Retrieves a connection definition from the Data Catalog.
GetConnection.name: GetConnection

GetConnections.documentation: Retrieves a list of connection definitions from the Data Catalog.
GetConnections.name: GetConnections

GetCrawlers.documentation: Retrieves metadata for all crawlers defined in the customer account.
GetCrawlers.name: GetCrawlers

GetDataCatalogEncryptionSettings.documentation: Retrieves the security configuration for a specified catalog.
GetDataCatalogEncryptionSettings.name: GetDataCatalogEncryptionSettings

GetDatabase.documentation: Retrieves the definition of a specified database.
GetDatabase.name: GetDatabase

GetDatabases.documentation: Retrieves all databases defined in a given Data Catalog.
GetDatabases.name: GetDatabases

GetDataflowGraph.documentation: Transforms a Python script into a directed acyclic graph (DAG).
GetDataflowGraph.name: GetDataflowGraph

GetDevEndpoint.documentation:
Retrieves information about a specified development endpoint.

When you create a development endpoint in a virtual private cloud (VPC), AWS Glue returns only a private IP address, and the public IP address field is not populated. When you create a non-VPC development endpoint, AWS Glue returns only a public IP address.
GetDevEndpoint.name: GetDevEndpoint

GetDevEndpoints.documentation:
Retrieves all the development endpoints in this AWS account.

When you create a development endpoint in a virtual private cloud (VPC), AWS Glue returns only a private IP address and the public IP address field is not populated. When you create a non-VPC development endpoint, AWS Glue returns only a public IP address.
GetDevEndpoints.name: GetDevEndpoints

GetJobBookmark.documentation: Returns information on a job bookmark entry.
GetJobBookmark.name: GetJobBookmark

GetJobRun.documentation: Retrieves the metadata for a given job run.
GetJobRun.name: GetJobRun

GetJobRuns.documentation: Retrieves metadata for all runs of a given job definition.
GetJobRuns.name: GetJobRuns

GetMLTaskRun.documentation: Gets details for a specific task run on a machine learning transform. Machine learning task runs are asynchronous tasks that AWS Glue runs on your behalf as part of various machine learning workflows. You can check the stats of any task run by calling GetMLTaskRun with the TaskRunID and its parent transform's TransformID.
GetMLTaskRun.name: GetMLTaskRun

GetMLTaskRuns.documentation:
Gets a list of runs for a machine learning transform. Machine learning task runs are asynchronous tasks that AWS Glue runs on your behalf as part of various machine learning workflows. You can get a sortable, filterable list of machine learning task runs by calling GetMLTaskRuns with their parent transform's TransformID and other optional parameters as documented in this section.

This operation returns a list of historic runs and must be paginated.
GetMLTaskRuns.name: GetMLTaskRuns

GetMLTransform.documentation: Gets an AWS Glue machine learning transform artifact and all its corresponding metadata. Machine learning transforms are a special type of transform that use machine learning to learn the details of the transformation to be performed by learning from examples provided by humans. These transformations are then saved by AWS Glue. You can retrieve their metadata by calling GetMLTransform.
GetMLTransform.name: GetMLTransform

GetMLTransforms.documentation: Gets a sortable, filterable list of existing AWS Glue machine learning transforms. Machine learning transforms are a special type of transform that use machine learning to learn the details of the transformation to be performed by learning from examples provided by humans. These transformations are then saved by AWS Glue, and you can retrieve their metadata by calling GetMLTransforms.
GetMLTransforms.name: GetMLTransforms

GetPartitions.documentation: Retrieves information about the partitions in a table.
GetPartitions.name: GetPartitions

GetPlan.documentation: Gets code to perform a specified mapping.
GetPlan.name: GetPlan

GetSecurityConfigurations.documentation: Retrieves a list of all security configurations.
GetSecurityConfigurations.name: GetSecurityConfigurations

GetTable.documentation: Retrieves the Table definition in a Data Catalog for a specified table.
GetTable.name: GetTable

GetTableVersion.documentation: Retrieves a specified version of a table.
GetTableVersion.name: GetTableVersion

GetTableVersions.documentation: Retrieves a list of strings that identify available versions of a specified table.
GetTableVersions.name: GetTableVersions

GetTables.documentation: Retrieves the definitions of some or all of the tables in a given Database.
GetTables.name: GetTables

GetTags.documentation: Retrieves a list of tags associated with a resource.
GetTags.name: GetTags

GetTriggers.documentation: Gets all the triggers associated with a job.
GetTriggers.name: GetTriggers

GetUserDefinedFunction.documentation: Retrieves a specified function definition from the Data Catalog.
GetUserDefinedFunction.name: GetUserDefinedFunction

GetUserDefinedFunctions.documentation: Retrieves multiple function definitions from the Data Catalog.
GetUserDefinedFunctions.name: GetUserDefinedFunctions

GetWorkflowRun.documentation: Retrieves the metadata for a given workflow run.
GetWorkflowRun.name: GetWorkflowRun

GetWorkflowRunProperties.documentation: Retrieves the workflow run properties which were set during the run.
GetWorkflowRunProperties.name: GetWorkflowRunProperties

GetWorkflowRuns.documentation: Retrieves metadata for all runs of a given workflow.
GetWorkflowRuns.name: GetWorkflowRuns

ImportCatalogToGlue.documentation: Imports an existing Amazon Athena Data Catalog to AWS Glue
ImportCatalogToGlue.name: ImportCatalogToGlue

ListCrawlers.documentation:
Retrieves the names of all crawler resources in this AWS account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.

This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag are retrieved.
ListCrawlers.name: ListCrawlers

ListDevEndpoints.documentation:
Retrieves the names of all DevEndpoint resources in this AWS account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.

This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag are retrieved.
ListDevEndpoints.name: ListDevEndpoints

ListJobs.documentation:
Retrieves the names of all job resources in this AWS account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.

This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag are retrieved.
ListJobs.name: ListJobs

ListMLTransforms.documentation: Retrieves a sortable, filterable list of existing AWS Glue machine learning transforms in this AWS account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter of the responses so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tag filtering, only resources with the tags are retrieved.
ListMLTransforms.name: ListMLTransforms

ListTriggers.documentation:
Retrieves the names of all trigger resources in this AWS account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.

This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag are retrieved.
ListTriggers.name: ListTriggers

ListWorkflows.documentation: Lists names of workflows created in the account.
ListWorkflows.name: ListWorkflows

PutDataCatalogEncryptionSettings.documentation: Sets the security configuration for a specified catalog. After the configuration has been set, the specified encryption is applied to every catalog write thereafter.
PutDataCatalogEncryptionSettings.name: PutDataCatalogEncryptionSettings

PutResourcePolicy.documentation: Sets the Data Catalog resource policy for access control.
PutResourcePolicy.name: PutResourcePolicy

PutWorkflowRunProperties.documentation: Puts the specified workflow run properties for the given workflow run. If a property already exists for the specified run, then it overrides the value otherwise adds the property to existing properties.
PutWorkflowRunProperties.name: PutWorkflowRunProperties

SearchTables.documentation:
Searches a set of tables based on properties in the table metadata as well as on the parent database. You can search against text or filter conditions.

You can only get tables that you have access to based on the security policies defined in Lake Formation. You need at least a read-only access to the table for it to be returned. If you do not have access to all the columns in the table, these columns will not be searched against when returning the list of tables back to you. If you have access to the columns but not the data in the columns, those columns and the associated metadata for those columns will be included in the search.
SearchTables.name: SearchTables

StartCrawler.documentation: Starts a crawl using the specified crawler, regardless of what is scheduled. If the crawler is already running, returns a CrawlerRunningException.
StartCrawler.name: StartCrawler

StartCrawlerSchedule.documentation: Changes the schedule state of the specified crawler to SCHEDULED, unless the crawler is already running or the schedule state is already SCHEDULED.
StartCrawlerSchedule.name: StartCrawlerSchedule

StartExportLabelsTaskRun.documentation: Begins an asynchronous task to export all labeled data for a particular transform. This task is the only label-related API call that is not part of the typical active learning workflow. You typically use StartExportLabelsTaskRun when you want to work with all of your existing labels at the same time, such as when you want to remove or change labels that were previously submitted as truth. This API operation accepts the TransformId whose labels you want to export and an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path to export the labels to. The operation returns a TaskRunId. You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun API.
StartExportLabelsTaskRun.name: StartExportLabelsTaskRun

StartImportLabelsTaskRun.documentation:
Enables you to provide additional labels (examples of truth) to be used to teach the machine learning transform and improve its quality. This API operation is generally used as part of the active learning workflow that starts with the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun call and that ultimately results in improving the quality of your machine learning transform.

After the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, AWS Glue machine learning will have generated a series of questions for humans to answer. (Answering these questions is often called 'labeling' in the machine learning workflows). In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?” After the labeling process is finished, users upload their answers/labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.

By default, StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun continually learns from and combines all labels that you upload unless you set Replace to true. If you set Replace to true, StartImportLabelsTaskRun deletes and forgets all previously uploaded labels and learns only from the exact set that you upload. Replacing labels can be helpful if you realize that you previously uploaded incorrect labels, and you believe that they are having a negative effect on your transform quality.

You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun operation.
StartImportLabelsTaskRun.name: StartImportLabelsTaskRun

StartJobRun.documentation: Starts a job run using a job definition.
StartJobRun.name: StartJobRun

StartMLEvaluationTaskRun.documentation:
Starts a task to estimate the quality of the transform.

When you provide label sets as examples of truth, AWS Glue machine learning uses some of those examples to learn from them. The rest of the labels are used as a test to estimate quality.

Returns a unique identifier for the run. You can call GetMLTaskRun to get more information about the stats of the EvaluationTaskRun.
StartMLEvaluationTaskRun.name: StartMLEvaluationTaskRun

StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun.documentation:
Starts the active learning workflow for your machine learning transform to improve the transform's quality by generating label sets and adding labels.

When the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, AWS Glue will have generated a "labeling set" or a set of questions for humans to answer.

In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?”

After the labeling process is finished, you can upload your labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform will use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.
StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun.name: StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun

StartTrigger.documentation: Starts an existing trigger. See Triggering Jobs for information about how different types of trigger are started.
StartTrigger.name: StartTrigger

StartWorkflowRun.documentation: Starts a new run of the specified workflow.
StartWorkflowRun.name: StartWorkflowRun

StopCrawler.documentation: If the specified crawler is running, stops the crawl.
StopCrawler.name: StopCrawler

StopCrawlerSchedule.documentation: Sets the schedule state of the specified crawler to NOT_SCHEDULED, but does not stop the crawler if it is already running.
StopCrawlerSchedule.name: StopCrawlerSchedule

TagResource.documentation: Adds tags to a resource. A tag is a label you can assign to an AWS resource. In AWS Glue, you can tag only certain resources. For information about what resources you can tag, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue.
TagResource.name: TagResource

UpdateClassifier.documentation: Modifies an existing classifier (a GrokClassifier, an XMLClassifier, a JsonClassifier, or a CsvClassifier, depending on which field is present).
UpdateClassifier.name: UpdateClassifier

UpdateConnection.documentation: Updates a connection definition in the Data Catalog.
UpdateConnection.name: UpdateConnection

UpdateCrawler.documentation: Updates a crawler. If a crawler is running, you must stop it using StopCrawler before updating it.
UpdateCrawler.name: UpdateCrawler

UpdateCrawlerSchedule.documentation: Updates the schedule of a crawler using a cron expression.
UpdateCrawlerSchedule.name: UpdateCrawlerSchedule

UpdateDatabase.documentation: Updates an existing database definition in a Data Catalog.
UpdateDatabase.name: UpdateDatabase

UpdateMLTransform.documentation:
Updates an existing machine learning transform. Call this operation to tune the algorithm parameters to achieve better results.

After calling this operation, you can call the StartMLEvaluationTaskRun operation to assess how well your new parameters achieved your goals (such as improving the quality of your machine learning transform, or making it more cost-effective).
UpdateMLTransform.name: UpdateMLTransform

UpdateTable.documentation: Updates a metadata table in the Data Catalog.
UpdateTable.name: UpdateTable

UpdateUserDefinedFunction.documentation: Updates an existing function definition in the Data Catalog.
UpdateUserDefinedFunction.name: UpdateUserDefinedFunction

Action.documentation: Defines an action to be initiated by a trigger.

Arguments.documentation:
The job arguments used when this trigger fires. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

CrawlerName.documentation: The name of the crawler to be used with this action.

JobName.documentation: The name of a job to be executed.

NotificationProperty.documentation: Specifies configuration properties of a job run notification.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this action.

Timeout.documentation: The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

AlreadyExistsException.documentation: A resource to be created or added already exists.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the catalog in which the partition is to be created. Currently, this should be the AWS account ID.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the metadata database in which the partition is to be created.

PartitionInputList.documentation: A list of PartitionInput structures that define the partitions to be created.

TableName.documentation: The name of the metadata table in which the partition is to be created.

Errors.documentation: The errors encountered when trying to create the requested partitions.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connections reside. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

ConnectionNameList.documentation: A list of names of the connections to delete.

Errors.documentation: A map of the names of connections that were not successfully deleted to error details.

Succeeded.documentation: A list of names of the connection definitions that were successfully deleted.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partition to be deleted resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the table in question resides.

PartitionsToDelete.documentation: A list of PartitionInput structures that define the partitions to be deleted.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table that contains the partitions to be deleted.

Errors.documentation: The errors encountered when trying to delete the requested partitions.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the table resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the tables to delete reside. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

TablesToDelete.documentation: A list of the table to delete.

Errors.documentation: A list of errors encountered in attempting to delete the specified tables.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the tables reside. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The database in the catalog in which the table resides. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

VersionIds.documentation: A list of the IDs of versions to be deleted. A VersionId is a string representation of an integer. Each version is incremented by 1.

Errors.documentation: A list of errors encountered while trying to delete the specified table versions.

CrawlerNames.documentation: A list of crawler names, which might be the names returned from the ListCrawlers operation.

CrawlersNotFound.documentation: A list of names of crawlers that were not found.

DevEndpointNames.documentation: The list of DevEndpoint names, which might be the names returned from the ListDevEndpoint operation.

JobNames.documentation: A list of job names, which might be the names returned from the ListJobs operation.

JobsNotFound.documentation: A list of names of jobs not found.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partitions in question reside. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database where the partitions reside.

PartitionsToGet.documentation: A list of partition values identifying the partitions to retrieve.

UnprocessedKeys.documentation: A list of the partition values in the request for which partitions were not returned.

TriggerNames.documentation: A list of trigger names, which may be the names returned from the ListTriggers operation.

TriggersNotFound.documentation: A list of names of triggers not found.

IncludeGraph.documentation: Specifies whether to include a graph when returning the workflow resource metadata.

Names.documentation: A list of workflow names, which may be the names returned from the ListWorkflows operation.

MissingWorkflows.documentation: A list of names of workflows not found.

BatchStopJobRunError.documentation: Records an error that occurred when attempting to stop a specified job run.

ErrorDetail.documentation: Specifies details about the error that was encountered.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job definition that is used in the job run in question.

JobRunId.documentation: The JobRunId of the job run in question.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job definition for which to stop job runs.

JobRunIds.documentation: A list of the JobRunIds that should be stopped for that job definition.

Errors.documentation: A list of the errors that were encountered in trying to stop JobRuns, including the JobRunId for which each error was encountered and details about the error.

SuccessfulSubmissions.documentation: A list of the JobRuns that were successfully submitted for stopping.

BatchStopJobRunSuccessfulSubmission.documentation: Records a successful request to stop a specified JobRun.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job definition used in the job run that was stopped.

JobRunId.documentation: The JobRunId of the job run that was stopped.

TaskRunId.documentation: A unique identifier for the task run.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the machine learning transform.

TaskRunId.documentation: The unique identifier for the task run.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the machine learning transform.

CatalogEntry.documentation: Specifies a table definition in the AWS Glue Data Catalog.

DatabaseName.documentation: The database in which the table metadata resides.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table in question.

ImportCompleted.documentation: True if the migration has completed, or False otherwise.

ImportTime.documentation: The time that the migration was started.

ImportedBy.documentation: The name of the person who initiated the migration.

CatalogTarget.documentation: Specifies an AWS Glue Data Catalog target.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database to be synchronized.

Tables.documentation: A list of the tables to be synchronized.

Classifier.documentation:
Classifiers are triggered during a crawl task. A classifier checks whether a given file is in a format it can handle. If it is, the classifier creates a schema in the form of a StructType object that matches that data format.

You can use the standard classifiers that AWS Glue provides, or you can write your own classifiers to best categorize your data sources and specify the appropriate schemas to use for them. A classifier can be a grok classifier, an XML classifier, a JSON classifier, or a custom CSV classifier, as specified in one of the fields in the Classifier object.

CloudWatchEncryption.documentation: Specifies how Amazon CloudWatch data should be encrypted.

CloudWatchEncryptionMode.documentation: The encryption mode to use for CloudWatch data.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the KMS key to be used to encrypt the data.

CodeGenEdge.documentation: Represents a directional edge in a directed acyclic graph (DAG).

Source.documentation: The ID of the node at which the edge starts.

Target.documentation: The ID of the node at which the edge ends.

CodeGenNode.documentation: Represents a node in a directed acyclic graph (DAG)

Args.documentation: Properties of the node, in the form of name-value pairs.

Id.documentation: A node identifier that is unique within the node's graph.

NodeType.documentation: The type of node that this is.

CodeGenNodeArg.documentation: An argument or property of a node.

Name.documentation: The name of the argument or property.

Param.documentation: True if the value is used as a parameter.

Value.documentation: The value of the argument or property.

Name.documentation: The name of the Column.

Parameters.documentation: These key-value pairs define properties associated with the column.

ConcurrentModificationException.documentation: Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.

ConcurrentRunsExceededException.documentation: Too many jobs are being run concurrently.

Condition.documentation: Defines a condition under which a trigger fires.

CrawlState.documentation: The state of the crawler to which this condition applies.

CrawlerName.documentation: The name of the crawler to which this condition applies.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job whose JobRuns this condition applies to, and on which this trigger waits.

State.documentation: The condition state. Currently, the values supported are SUCCEEDED, STOPPED, TIMEOUT, and FAILED.

ConfusionMatrix.documentation:
The confusion matrix shows you what your transform is predicting accurately and what types of errors it is making.

For more information, see Confusion matrix in Wikipedia.

NumFalseNegatives.documentation: The number of matches in the data that the transform didn't find, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

NumFalsePositives.documentation: The number of nonmatches in the data that the transform incorrectly classified as a match, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

NumTrueNegatives.documentation: The number of nonmatches in the data that the transform correctly rejected, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

NumTruePositives.documentation: The number of matches in the data that the transform correctly found, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

Connection.documentation: Defines a connection to a data source.

ConnectionProperties.documentation:
These key-value pairs define parameters for the connection:

  • HOST - The host URI: either the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) or the IPv4 address of the database host.

  • PORT - The port number, between 1024 and 65535, of the port on which the database host is listening for database connections.

  • USER_NAME - The name under which to log in to the database. The value string for USER_NAME is "USERNAME".

  • PASSWORD - A password, if one is used, for the user name.

  • ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD - When you enable connection password protection by setting ConnectionPasswordEncryption in the Data Catalog encryption settings, this field stores the encrypted password.

  • JDBC_DRIVER_JAR_URI - The Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path of the JAR file that contains the JDBC driver to use.

  • JDBC_DRIVER_CLASS_NAME - The class name of the JDBC driver to use.

  • JDBC_ENGINE - The name of the JDBC engine to use.

  • JDBC_ENGINE_VERSION - The version of the JDBC engine to use.

  • CONFIG_FILES - (Reserved for future use.)

  • INSTANCE_ID - The instance ID to use.

  • JDBC_CONNECTION_URL - The URL for connecting to a JDBC data source.

  • JDBC_ENFORCE_SSL - A Boolean string (true, false) specifying whether Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) with hostname matching is enforced for the JDBC connection on the client. The default is false.

  • CUSTOM_JDBC_CERT - An Amazon S3 location specifying the customer's root certificate. AWS Glue uses this root certificate to validate the customer’s certificate when connecting to the customer database. AWS Glue only handles X.509 certificates. The certificate provided must be DER-encoded and supplied in Base64 encoding PEM format.

  • SKIP_CUSTOM_JDBC_CERT_VALIDATION - By default, this is false. AWS Glue validates the Signature algorithm and Subject Public Key Algorithm for the customer certificate. The only permitted algorithms for the Signature algorithm are SHA256withRSA, SHA384withRSA or SHA512withRSA. For the Subject Public Key Algorithm, the key length must be at least 2048. You can set the value of this property to true to skip AWS Glue’s validation of the customer certificate.

  • CUSTOM_JDBC_CERT_STRING - A custom JDBC certificate string which is used for domain match or distinguished name match to prevent a man-in-the-middle attack. In Oracle database, this is used as the SSL_SERVER_CERT_DN; in Microsoft SQL Server, this is used as the hostNameInCertificate.

  • CONNECTION_URL - The URL for connecting to a general (non-JDBC) data source.

ConnectionType.documentation: The type of the connection. Currently, only JDBC is supported; SFTP is not supported.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that this connection definition was created.

LastUpdatedBy.documentation: The user, group, or role that last updated this connection definition.

LastUpdatedTime.documentation: The last time that this connection definition was updated.

MatchCriteria.documentation: A list of criteria that can be used in selecting this connection.

Name.documentation: The name of the connection definition.

PhysicalConnectionRequirements.documentation: A map of physical connection requirements, such as virtual private cloud (VPC) and SecurityGroup, that are needed to make this connection successfully.

ConnectionInput.documentation: A structure that is used to specify a connection to create or update.

ConnectionProperties.documentation: These key-value pairs define parameters for the connection.

ConnectionType.documentation:
The type of the connection. Currently, these types are supported:

  • JDBC - Designates a connection to a database through Java Database Connectivity (JDBC).

  • MONGODB - Designates a connection to a MongoDB document database.

SFTP is not supported.

MatchCriteria.documentation: A list of criteria that can be used in selecting this connection.

Name.documentation: The name of the connection.

PhysicalConnectionRequirements.documentation: A map of physical connection requirements, such as virtual private cloud (VPC) and SecurityGroup, that are needed to successfully make this connection.

ConnectionPasswordEncryption.documentation:
The data structure used by the Data Catalog to encrypt the password as part of CreateConnection or UpdateConnection and store it in the ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD field in the connection properties. You can enable catalog encryption or only password encryption.

When a CreationConnection request arrives containing a password, the Data Catalog first encrypts the password using your AWS KMS key. It then encrypts the whole connection object again if catalog encryption is also enabled.

This encryption requires that you set AWS KMS key permissions to enable or restrict access on the password key according to your security requirements. For example, you might want only administrators to have decrypt permission on the password key.

AwsKmsKeyId.documentation:
An AWS KMS key that is used to encrypt the connection password.

If connection password protection is enabled, the caller of CreateConnection and UpdateConnection needs at least kms:Encrypt permission on the specified AWS KMS key, to encrypt passwords before storing them in the Data Catalog.

You can set the decrypt permission to enable or restrict access on the password key according to your security requirements.

ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted.documentation: When the ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted flag is set to "true", passwords remain encrypted in the responses of GetConnection and GetConnections. This encryption takes effect independently from catalog encryption.

ConnectionsList.documentation: Specifies the connections used by a job.

Connections.documentation: A list of connections used by the job.

Crawl.documentation: The details of a crawl in the workflow.

CompletedOn.documentation: The date and time on which the crawl completed.

ErrorMessage.documentation: The error message associated with the crawl.

LogGroup.documentation: The log group associated with the crawl.

LogStream.documentation: The log stream associated with the crawl.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time on which the crawl started.

Crawler.documentation: Specifies a crawler program that examines a data source and uses classifiers to try to determine its schema. If successful, the crawler records metadata concerning the data source in the AWS Glue Data Catalog.

Classifiers.documentation: A list of UTF-8 strings that specify the custom classifiers that are associated with the crawler.

Configuration.documentation: Crawler configuration information. This versioned JSON string allows users to specify aspects of a crawler's behavior. For more information, see Configuring a Crawler.

CrawlElapsedTime.documentation: If the crawler is running, contains the total time elapsed since the last crawl began.

CrawlerSecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used by this crawler.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that the crawler was created.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database in which the crawler's output is stored.

LastCrawl.documentation: The status of the last crawl, and potentially error information if an error occurred.

LastUpdated.documentation: The time that the crawler was last updated.

Name.documentation: The name of the crawler.

Role.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM role that's used to access customer resources, such as Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) data.

Schedule.documentation: For scheduled crawlers, the schedule when the crawler runs.

SchemaChangePolicy.documentation: The policy that specifies update and delete behaviors for the crawler.

State.documentation: Indicates whether the crawler is running, or whether a run is pending.

TablePrefix.documentation: The prefix added to the names of tables that are created.

LastRuntimeSeconds.documentation: The duration of the crawler's most recent run, in seconds.

MedianRuntimeSeconds.documentation: The median duration of this crawler's runs, in seconds.

StillEstimating.documentation: True if the crawler is still estimating how long it will take to complete this run.

TablesCreated.documentation: The number of tables created by this crawler.

TablesDeleted.documentation: The number of tables deleted by this crawler.

TablesUpdated.documentation: The number of tables updated by this crawler.

TimeLeftSeconds.documentation: The estimated time left to complete a running crawl.

CrawlerNodeDetails.documentation: The details of a Crawler node present in the workflow.

Crawls.documentation: A list of crawls represented by the crawl node.

CrawlerRunningException.documentation: The operation cannot be performed because the crawler is already running.

S3Targets.documentation: Specifies Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) targets.

CsvClassifier.documentation: A CsvClassifier object specifying the classifier to create.

GrokClassifier.documentation: A GrokClassifier object specifying the classifier to create.

JsonClassifier.documentation: A JsonClassifier object specifying the classifier to create.

XMLClassifier.documentation: An XMLClassifier object specifying the classifier to create.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the connection. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

ConnectionInput.documentation: A ConnectionInput object defining the connection to create.

Classifiers.documentation: A list of custom classifiers that the user has registered. By default, all built-in classifiers are included in a crawl, but these custom classifiers always override the default classifiers for a given classification.

Configuration.documentation: The crawler configuration information. This versioned JSON string allows users to specify aspects of a crawler's behavior. For more information, see Configuring a Crawler.

CrawlerSecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used by this crawler.

DatabaseName.documentation: The AWS Glue database where results are written, such as: arn:aws:daylight:us-east-1::database/sometable/*.

Name.documentation: Name of the new crawler.

Role.documentation: The IAM role or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM role used by the new crawler to access customer resources.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule. For more information, see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, specify cron(15 12 * * ? *).

SchemaChangePolicy.documentation: The policy for the crawler's update and deletion behavior.

TablePrefix.documentation: The table prefix used for catalog tables that are created.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this crawler request. You can use tags to limit access to the crawler. For more information, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue.

Targets.documentation: A list of collection of targets to crawl.

CreateCsvClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a custom CSV classifier for CreateClassifier to create.

AllowSingleColumn.documentation: Enables the processing of files that contain only one column.

ContainsHeader.documentation: Indicates whether the CSV file contains a header.

Delimiter.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what separates each column entry in the row.

DisableValueTrimming.documentation: Specifies not to trim values before identifying the type of column values. The default value is true.

Header.documentation: A list of strings representing column names.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

QuoteSymbol.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what combines content into a single column value. Must be different from the column delimiter.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the database. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

Arguments.documentation: A map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

EndpointName.documentation: The name to be assigned to the new DevEndpoint.

ExtraJarsS3Path.documentation: The path to one or more Java .jar files in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.documentation:
The paths to one or more Python libraries in an Amazon S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

You can only use pure Python libraries with a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not yet supported.

GlueVersion.documentation:
Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that AWS Glue supports. The Python version indicates the version supported for running your ETL scripts on development endpoints.

For more information about the available AWS Glue versions and corresponding Spark and Python versions, see Glue version in the developer guide.

Development endpoints that are created without specifying a Glue version default to Glue 0.9.

You can specify a version of Python support for development endpoints by using the Arguments parameter in the CreateDevEndpoint or UpdateDevEndpoint APIs. If no arguments are provided, the version defaults to Python 2.

NumberOfNodes.documentation: The number of AWS Glue Data Processing Units (DPUs) to allocate to this DevEndpoint.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated to the development endpoint.

The maximum number of workers you can define are 299 for G.1X, and 149 for G.2X.

PublicKey.documentation: The public key to be used by this DevEndpoint for authentication. This attribute is provided for backward compatibility because the recommended attribute to use is public keys.

PublicKeys.documentation:
A list of public keys to be used by the development endpoints for authentication. The use of this attribute is preferred over a single public key because the public keys allow you to have a different private key per client.

If you previously created an endpoint with a public key, you must remove that key to be able to set a list of public keys. Call the UpdateDevEndpoint API with the public key content in the deletePublicKeys attribute, and the list of new keys in the addPublicKeys attribute.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this DevEndpoint.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation: Security group IDs for the security groups to be used by the new DevEndpoint.

SubnetId.documentation: The subnet ID for the new DevEndpoint to use.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this DevEndpoint. You may use tags to limit access to the DevEndpoint. For more information about tags in AWS Glue, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue in the developer guide.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated to the development endpoint. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker maps to 1 DPU (4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory, 64 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 DPU (8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory, 128 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

Known issue: when a development endpoint is created with the G.2X WorkerType configuration, the Spark drivers for the development endpoint will run on 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory, and a 64 GB disk.

Arguments.documentation:
The map of arguments used to configure this DevEndpoint.

Valid arguments are:

  • "--enable-glue-datacatalog": ""

  • "GLUE_PYTHON_VERSION": "3"

  • "GLUE_PYTHON_VERSION": "2"

You can specify a version of Python support for development endpoints by using the Arguments parameter in the CreateDevEndpoint or UpdateDevEndpoint APIs. If no arguments are provided, the version defaults to Python 2.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The AWS Availability Zone where this DevEndpoint is located.

CreatedTimestamp.documentation: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was created.

ExtraJarsS3Path.documentation: Path to one or more Java .jar files in an S3 bucket that will be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.documentation: The paths to one or more Python libraries in an S3 bucket that will be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

FailureReason.documentation: The reason for a current failure in this DevEndpoint.

GlueVersion.documentation: Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that AWS Glue supports. The Python version indicates the version supported for running your ETL scripts on development endpoints.

NumberOfNodes.documentation: The number of AWS Glue Data Processing Units (DPUs) allocated to this DevEndpoint.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation: The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated to the development endpoint.

RoleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role assigned to the new DevEndpoint.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure being used with this DevEndpoint.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation: The security groups assigned to the new DevEndpoint.

SubnetId.documentation: The subnet ID assigned to the new DevEndpoint.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private cloud (VPC) used by this DevEndpoint.

WorkerType.documentation: The type of predefined worker that is allocated to the development endpoint. May be a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

YarnEndpointAddress.documentation: The address of the YARN endpoint used by this DevEndpoint.

ZeppelinRemoteSparkInterpreterPort.documentation: The Apache Zeppelin port for the remote Apache Spark interpreter.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches, such as Twitter, JSON, Omniture logs, Amazon CloudWatch Logs, and so on.

CustomPatterns.documentation: Optional custom grok patterns used by this classifier.

GrokPattern.documentation: The grok pattern used by this classifier.

Name.documentation: The name of the new classifier.

AllocatedCapacity.deprecatedMessage: This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.
AllocatedCapacity.documentation:
This parameter is deprecated. Use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) to allocate to this Job. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

DefaultArguments.documentation:
The default arguments for this job.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

ExecutionProperty.documentation: An ExecutionProperty specifying the maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for this job.

GlueVersion.documentation:
Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that AWS Glue supports. The Python version indicates the version supported for jobs of type Spark.

For more information about the available AWS Glue versions and corresponding Spark and Python versions, see Glue version in the developer guide.

Jobs that are created without specifying a Glue version default to Glue 0.9.

LogUri.documentation: This field is reserved for future use.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

Do not set Max Capacity if using WorkerType and NumberOfWorkers.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a Python shell job or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a Python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry this job if it fails.

Name.documentation: The name you assign to this job definition. It must be unique in your account.

NonOverridableArguments.documentation: Non-overridable arguments for this job, specified as name-value pairs.

NotificationProperty.documentation: Specifies configuration properties of a job notification.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when a job runs.

The maximum number of workers you can define are 299 for G.1X, and 149 for G.2X.

Role.documentation: The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role associated with this job.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this job. You may use tags to limit access to the job. For more information about tags in AWS Glue, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue in the developer guide.

Timeout.documentation: The job timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when a job runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker maps to 1 DPU (4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory, 64 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 DPU (8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory, 128 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

Name.documentation: The unique name that was provided for this job definition.

CreateJsonClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a JSON classifier for CreateClassifier to create.

JsonPath.documentation: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. AWS Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

Description.documentation: A description of the machine learning transform that is being defined. The default is an empty string.

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of AWS Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see AWS Glue Versions in the developer guide.

InputRecordTables.documentation: A list of AWS Glue table definitions used by the transform.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

MaxCapacity is a mutually exclusive option with NumberOfWorkers and WorkerType.

  • If either NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType is set, then MaxCapacity cannot be set.

  • If MaxCapacity is set then neither NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType can be set.

  • If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

  • MaxCapacity and NumberOfWorkers must both be at least 1.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry a task for this transform after a task run fails.

Name.documentation: The unique name that you give the transform when you create it.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when this task runs.

If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

Parameters.documentation: The algorithmic parameters that are specific to the transform type used. Conditionally dependent on the transform type.

Role.documentation:
The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions. The required permissions include both AWS Glue service role permissions to AWS Glue resources, and Amazon S3 permissions required by the transform.

  • This role needs AWS Glue service role permissions to allow access to resources in AWS Glue. See Attach a Policy to IAM Users That Access AWS Glue.

  • This role needs permission to your Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) sources, targets, temporary directory, scripts, and any libraries used by the task run for this transform.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this machine learning transform. You may use tags to limit access to the machine learning transform. For more information about tags in AWS Glue, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue in the developer guide.

Timeout.documentation: The timeout of the task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when this task runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

MaxCapacity is a mutually exclusive option with NumberOfWorkers and WorkerType.

  • If either NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType is set, then MaxCapacity cannot be set.

  • If MaxCapacity is set then neither NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType can be set.

  • If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

  • MaxCapacity and NumberOfWorkers must both be at least 1.

TransformId.documentation: A unique identifier that is generated for the transform.

CatalogId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the catalog in which the partition is to be created.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the metadata database in which the partition is to be created.

PartitionInput.documentation: A PartitionInput structure defining the partition to be created.

TableName.documentation: The name of the metadata table in which the partition is to be created.

DagEdges.documentation: A list of the edges in the DAG.

DagNodes.documentation: A list of the nodes in the DAG.

Language.documentation: The programming language of the resulting code from the DAG.

PythonScript.documentation: The Python script generated from the DAG.

ScalaCode.documentation: The Scala code generated from the DAG.

EncryptionConfiguration.documentation: The encryption configuration for the new security configuration.

Name.documentation: The name for the new security configuration.

CreatedTimestamp.documentation: The time at which the new security configuration was created.

Name.documentation: The name assigned to the new security configuration.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the Table. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The catalog database in which to create the new table. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

TableInput.documentation: The TableInput object that defines the metadata table to create in the catalog.

Actions.documentation: The actions initiated by this trigger when it fires.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger.

Predicate.documentation:
A predicate to specify when the new trigger should fire.

This field is required when the trigger type is CONDITIONAL.

Schedule.documentation:
A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

This field is required when the trigger type is SCHEDULED.

StartOnCreation.documentation: Set to true to start SCHEDULED and CONDITIONAL triggers when created. True is not supported for ON_DEMAND triggers.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this trigger. You may use tags to limit access to the trigger. For more information about tags in AWS Glue, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue in the developer guide.

WorkflowName.documentation: The name of the workflow associated with the trigger.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the function. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which to create the function.

FunctionInput.documentation: A FunctionInput object that defines the function to create in the Data Catalog.

DefaultRunProperties.documentation: A collection of properties to be used as part of each execution of the workflow.

Name.documentation: The name to be assigned to the workflow. It should be unique within your account.

Tags.documentation: The tags to be used with this workflow.

Name.documentation: The name of the workflow which was provided as part of the request.

CreateXMLClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies an XML classifier for CreateClassifier to create.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

RowTag.documentation: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. This can't identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

AllowSingleColumn.documentation: Enables the processing of files that contain only one column.

ContainsHeader.documentation: Indicates whether the CSV file contains a header.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that this classifier was registered.

Delimiter.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what separates each column entry in the row.

DisableValueTrimming.documentation: Specifies not to trim values before identifying the type of column values. The default value is true.

Header.documentation: A list of strings representing column names.

LastUpdated.documentation: The time that this classifier was last updated.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

QuoteSymbol.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what combines content into a single column value. It must be different from the column delimiter.

DataCatalogEncryptionSettings.documentation: Contains configuration information for maintaining Data Catalog security.

ConnectionPasswordEncryption.documentation: When connection password protection is enabled, the Data Catalog uses a customer-provided key to encrypt the password as part of CreateConnection or UpdateConnection and store it in the ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD field in the connection properties. You can enable catalog encryption or only password encryption.

EncryptionAtRest.documentation: Specifies the encryption-at-rest configuration for the Data Catalog.

DataLakePrincipalIdentifier.documentation: An identifier for the AWS Lake Formation principal.

Database.documentation: The Database object represents a logical grouping of tables that might reside in a Hive metastore or an RDBMS.

CreateTableDefaultPermissions.documentation: Creates a set of default permissions on the table for principals.

CreateTime.documentation: The time at which the metadata database was created in the catalog.

LocationUri.documentation: The location of the database (for example, an HDFS path).

Name.documentation: The name of the database. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

Parameters.documentation: These key-value pairs define parameters and properties of the database.

DatabaseInput.documentation: The structure used to create or update a database.

CreateTableDefaultPermissions.documentation: Creates a set of default permissions on the table for principals.

LocationUri.documentation: The location of the database (for example, an HDFS path).

Name.documentation: The name of the database. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

Parameters.documentation:
These key-value pairs define parameters and properties of the database.

These key-value pairs define parameters and properties of the database.

Name.documentation: Name of the classifier to remove.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connection resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

ConnectionName.documentation: The name of the connection to delete.

Name.documentation: The name of the crawler to remove.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the database resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

Name.documentation: The name of the database to delete. For Hive compatibility, this must be all lowercase.
