DevEndpoint.documentation: A development endpoint where a developer can remotely debug extract, transform, and load (ETL) scripts.

Arguments.documentation:
A map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

Valid arguments are:

  • "--enable-glue-datacatalog": ""

  • "GLUE_PYTHON_VERSION": "3"

  • "GLUE_PYTHON_VERSION": "2"

You can specify a version of Python support for development endpoints by using the Arguments parameter in the CreateDevEndpoint or UpdateDevEndpoint APIs. If no arguments are provided, the version defaults to Python 2.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The AWS Availability Zone where this DevEndpoint is located.

CreatedTimestamp.documentation: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was created.

ExtraJarsS3Path.documentation:
The path to one or more Java .jar files in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

You can only use pure Java/Scala libraries with a DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.documentation:
The paths to one or more Python libraries in an Amazon S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

You can only use pure Python libraries with a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not currently supported.

FailureReason.documentation: The reason for a current failure in this DevEndpoint.

GlueVersion.documentation:
Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that AWS Glue supports. The Python version indicates the version supported for running your ETL scripts on development endpoints.

For more information about the available AWS Glue versions and corresponding Spark and Python versions, see Glue version in the developer guide.

Development endpoints that are created without specifying a Glue version default to Glue 0.9.

You can specify a version of Python support for development endpoints by using the Arguments parameter in the CreateDevEndpoint or UpdateDevEndpoint APIs. If no arguments are provided, the version defaults to Python 2.

LastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was last modified.

NumberOfNodes.documentation: The number of AWS Glue Data Processing Units (DPUs) allocated to this DevEndpoint.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated to the development endpoint.

The maximum number of workers you can define are 299 for G.1X, and 149 for G.2X.

PrivateAddress.documentation: A private IP address to access the DevEndpoint within a VPC if the DevEndpoint is created within one. The PrivateAddress field is present only when you create the DevEndpoint within your VPC.

PublicAddress.documentation: The public IP address used by this DevEndpoint. The PublicAddress field is present only when you create a non-virtual private cloud (VPC) DevEndpoint.

PublicKey.documentation: The public key to be used by this DevEndpoint for authentication. This attribute is provided for backward compatibility because the recommended attribute to use is public keys.

PublicKeys.documentation:
A list of public keys to be used by the DevEndpoints for authentication. Using this attribute is preferred over a single public key because the public keys allow you to have a different private key per client.

If you previously created an endpoint with a public key, you must remove that key to be able to set a list of public keys. Call the UpdateDevEndpoint API operation with the public key content in the deletePublicKeys attribute, and the list of new keys in the addPublicKeys attribute.

RoleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role used in this DevEndpoint.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this DevEndpoint.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation: A list of security group identifiers used in this DevEndpoint.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private cloud (VPC) used by this DevEndpoint.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated to the development endpoint. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker maps to 1 DPU (4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory, 64 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 DPU (8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory, 128 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

Known issue: when a development endpoint is created with the G.2X WorkerType configuration, the Spark drivers for the development endpoint will run on 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory, and a 64 GB disk.

YarnEndpointAddress.documentation: The YARN endpoint address used by this DevEndpoint.

ZeppelinRemoteSparkInterpreterPort.documentation: The Apache Zeppelin port for the remote Apache Spark interpreter.

DevEndpointCustomLibraries.documentation: Custom libraries to be loaded into a development endpoint.

ExtraJarsS3Path.documentation:
The path to one or more Java .jar files in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

You can only use pure Java/Scala libraries with a DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.documentation:
The paths to one or more Python libraries in an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

You can only use pure Python libraries with a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not currently supported.

DynamoDBTarget.documentation: Specifies an Amazon DynamoDB table to crawl.

Path.documentation: The name of the DynamoDB table to crawl.

Edge.documentation: An edge represents a directed connection between two AWS Glue components which are part of the workflow the edge belongs to.

DestinationId.documentation: The unique of the node within the workflow where the edge ends.

SourceId.documentation: The unique of the node within the workflow where the edge starts.

EncryptionAtRest.documentation: Specifies the encryption-at-rest configuration for the Data Catalog.

CatalogEncryptionMode.documentation: The encryption-at-rest mode for encrypting Data Catalog data.

SseAwsKmsKeyId.documentation: The ID of the AWS KMS key to use for encryption at rest.

S3Encryption.documentation: The encryption configuration for Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) data.

EvaluationMetrics.documentation: Evaluation metrics provide an estimate of the quality of your machine learning transform.

FindMatchesMetrics.documentation: The evaluation metrics for the find matches algorithm.

MaxConcurrentRuns.documentation: The maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for the job. The default is 1. An error is returned when this threshold is reached. The maximum value you can specify is controlled by a service limit.

ExportLabelsTaskRunProperties.documentation: Specifies configuration properties for an exporting labels task run.

OutputS3Path.documentation: The Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path where you will export the labels.

FindMatchesMetrics.documentation: The evaluation metrics for the find matches algorithm. The quality of your machine learning transform is measured by getting your transform to predict some matches and comparing the results to known matches from the same dataset. The quality metrics are based on a subset of your data, so they are not precise.

AreaUnderPRCurve.documentation:
The area under the precision/recall curve (AUPRC) is a single number measuring the overall quality of the transform, that is independent of the choice made for precision vs. recall. Higher values indicate that you have a more attractive precision vs. recall tradeoff.

For more information, see Precision and recall in Wikipedia.

ConfusionMatrix.documentation:
The confusion matrix shows you what your transform is predicting accurately and what types of errors it is making.

For more information, see Confusion matrix in Wikipedia.

F1.documentation:
The maximum F1 metric indicates the transform's accuracy between 0 and 1, where 1 is the best accuracy.

For more information, see F1 score in Wikipedia.

Precision.documentation:
The precision metric indicates when often your transform is correct when it predicts a match. Specifically, it measures how well the transform finds true positives from the total true positives possible.

For more information, see Precision and recall in Wikipedia.

Recall.documentation:
The recall metric indicates that for an actual match, how often your transform predicts the match. Specifically, it measures how well the transform finds true positives from the total records in the source data.

For more information, see Precision and recall in Wikipedia.

FindMatchesParameters.documentation: The parameters to configure the find matches transform.

AccuracyCostTradeoff.documentation:
The value that is selected when tuning your transform for a balance between accuracy and cost. A value of 0.5 means that the system balances accuracy and cost concerns. A value of 1.0 means a bias purely for accuracy, which typically results in a higher cost, sometimes substantially higher. A value of 0.0 means a bias purely for cost, which results in a less accurate FindMatches transform, sometimes with unacceptable accuracy.

Accuracy measures how well the transform finds true positives and true negatives. Increasing accuracy requires more machine resources and cost. But it also results in increased recall.

Cost measures how many compute resources, and thus money, are consumed to run the transform.

EnforceProvidedLabels.documentation:
The value to switch on or off to force the output to match the provided labels from users. If the value is True, the find matches transform forces the output to match the provided labels. The results override the normal conflation results. If the value is False, the find matches transform does not ensure all the labels provided are respected, and the results rely on the trained model.

Note that setting this value to true may increase the conflation execution time.

PrecisionRecallTradeoff.documentation:
The value selected when tuning your transform for a balance between precision and recall. A value of 0.5 means no preference; a value of 1.0 means a bias purely for precision, and a value of 0.0 means a bias for recall. Because this is a tradeoff, choosing values close to 1.0 means very low recall, and choosing values close to 0.0 results in very low precision.

The precision metric indicates how often your model is correct when it predicts a match.

The recall metric indicates that for an actual match, how often your model predicts the match.

A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

Status.documentation: The last known status of the transform (to indicate whether it can be used or not). One of "NOT_READY", "READY", or "DELETING".

Timeout.documentation: The timeout for a task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the transform, generated at the time that the transform was created.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partitions in question reside. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database where the partitions reside.

Expression.documentation:
An expression that filters the partitions to be returned.

The expression uses SQL syntax similar to the SQL WHERE filter clause. The SQL statement parser JSQLParser parses the expression.

Operators: The following are the operators that you can use in the Expression API call:

=

Checks whether the values of the two operands are equal; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: Assume 'variable a' holds 10 and 'variable b' holds 20.

(a = b) is not true.

< >

Checks whether the values of two operands are equal; if the values are not equal, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a < > b) is true.

>

Checks whether the value of the left operand is greater than the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a > b) is not true.

<

Checks whether the value of the left operand is less than the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a < b) is true.

>=

Checks whether the value of the left operand is greater than or equal to the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a >= b) is not true.

<=

Checks whether the value of the left operand is less than or equal to the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a <= b) is true.

AND, OR, IN, BETWEEN, LIKE, NOT, IS NULL

Logical operators.

Supported Partition Key Types: The following are the supported partition keys.

  • string

  • date

  • timestamp

  • int

  • bigint

  • long

  • tinyint

  • smallint

  • decimal

If an invalid type is encountered, an exception is thrown.

The following list shows the valid operators on each type. When you define a crawler, the partitionKey type is created as a STRING, to be compatible with the catalog partitions.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) allocated to runs of this job. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

DefaultArguments.documentation:
The default arguments for this job, specified as name-value pairs.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

GlueVersion.documentation:
Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that AWS Glue supports. The Python version indicates the version supported for jobs of type Spark.

For more information about the available AWS Glue versions and corresponding Spark and Python versions, see Glue version in the developer guide.

Jobs that are created without specifying a Glue version default to Glue 0.9.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The last point in time when this job definition was modified.

LogUri.documentation: This field is reserved for future use.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

Do not set Max Capacity if using WorkerType and NumberOfWorkers.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a Python shell job or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a Python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry this job after a JobRun fails.

Name.documentation: The name you assign to this job definition.

NonOverridableArguments.documentation: Non-overridable arguments for this job, specified as name-value pairs.

NotificationProperty.documentation: Specifies configuration properties of a job notification.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when a job runs.

The maximum number of workers you can define are 299 for G.1X, and 149 for G.2X.

Role.documentation: The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role associated with this job.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job.

Timeout.documentation: The job timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when a job runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker maps to 1 DPU (4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory, 64 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 DPU (8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory, 128 GB disk), and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for memory-intensive jobs.

JobBookmarkEntry.documentation: Defines a point that a job can resume processing.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job in question.

PreviousRunId.documentation: The unique run identifier associated with the previous job run.

JobBookmarksEncryption.documentation: Specifies how job bookmark data should be encrypted.

JobBookmarksEncryptionMode.documentation: The encryption mode to use for job bookmarks data.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the KMS key to be used to encrypt the data.

JobCommand.documentation: Specifies code executed when a job is run.

Name.documentation: The name of the job command. For an Apache Spark ETL job, this must be glueetl. For a Python shell job, it must be pythonshell.

PythonVersion.documentation: The Python version being used to execute a Python shell job. Allowed values are 2 or 3.

ScriptLocation.documentation: Specifies the Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path to a script that executes a job.

JobNodeDetails.documentation: The details of a Job node present in the workflow.

JobRuns.documentation: The information for the job runs represented by the job node.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) allocated to this JobRun. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

Arguments.documentation:
The job arguments associated with this run. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

Attempt.documentation: The number of the attempt to run this job.

CompletedOn.documentation: The date and time that this job run completed.

ErrorMessage.documentation: An error message associated with this job run.

ExecutionTime.documentation: The amount of time (in seconds) that the job run consumed resources.

Jobs that are created without specifying a Glue version default to Glue 0.9.

JobRunState.documentation: The current state of the job run.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The last time that this job run was modified.

LogGroupName.documentation: The name of the log group for secure logging that can be server-side encrypted in Amazon CloudWatch using AWS KMS. This name can be /aws-glue/jobs/, in which case the default encryption is NONE. If you add a role name and SecurityConfiguration name (in other words, /aws-glue/jobs-yourRoleName-yourSecurityConfigurationName/), then that security configuration is used to encrypt the log group.

JobUpdate.documentation: Specifies information used to update an existing job definition. The previous job definition is completely overwritten by this information.

JsonPath.documentation: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. AWS Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

ErrorMessage.documentation: If an error occurred, the error information about the last crawl.

LogGroup.documentation: The log group for the last crawl.

LogStream.documentation: The log stream for the last crawl.

MessagePrefix.documentation: The prefix for a message about this crawl.

StartTime.documentation: The time at which the crawl started.

DependentJobName.documentation: The name of the job for which to retrieve triggers. The trigger that can start this job is returned. If there is no such trigger, all triggers are returned.

A continuation token, if not all workflow names have been returned.

Workflows.documentation: List of names of workflows in the account.

S3.documentation: An Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) location.

MLTransform.documentation: A structure for a machine learning transform.

CreatedOn.documentation: A timestamp. The time and date that this machine learning transform was created.

Description.documentation: A user-defined, long-form description text for the machine learning transform. Descriptions are not guaranteed to be unique and can be changed at any time.

EvaluationMetrics.documentation: An EvaluationMetrics object. Evaluation metrics provide an estimate of the quality of your machine learning transform.

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of AWS Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see AWS Glue Versions in the developer guide.

InputRecordTables.documentation: A list of AWS Glue table definitions used by the transform.

LabelCount.documentation: A count identifier for the labeling files generated by AWS Glue for this transform. As you create a better transform, you can iteratively download, label, and upload the labeling file.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: A timestamp. The last point in time when this machine learning transform was modified.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

MaxCapacity is a mutually exclusive option with NumberOfWorkers and WorkerType.

  • If either NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType is set, then MaxCapacity cannot be set.

  • If MaxCapacity is set then neither NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType can be set.

  • If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

  • MaxCapacity and NumberOfWorkers must both be at least 1.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry after an MLTaskRun of the machine learning transform fails.

Name.documentation: A user-defined name for the machine learning transform. Names are not guaranteed unique and can be changed at any time.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when a task of the transform runs.

If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

Parameters.documentation: A TransformParameters object. You can use parameters to tune (customize) the behavior of the machine learning transform by specifying what data it learns from and your preference on various tradeoffs (such as precious vs. recall, or accuracy vs. cost).

Role.documentation:
The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions. The required permissions include both AWS Glue service role permissions to AWS Glue resources, and Amazon S3 permissions required by the transform.

  • This role needs AWS Glue service role permissions to allow access to resources in AWS Glue. See Attach a Policy to IAM Users That Access AWS Glue.

  • This role needs permission to your Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) sources, targets, temporary directory, scripts, and any libraries used by the task run for this transform.

Schema.documentation: A map of key-value pairs representing the columns and data types that this transform can run against. Has an upper bound of 100 columns.

Status.documentation: The current status of the machine learning transform.

Timeout.documentation: The timeout in minutes of the machine learning transform.

TransformId.documentation: The unique transform ID that is generated for the machine learning transform. The ID is guaranteed to be unique and does not change.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when a task of this transform runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

MaxCapacity is a mutually exclusive option with NumberOfWorkers and WorkerType.

  • If either NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType is set, then MaxCapacity cannot be set.

  • If MaxCapacity is set then neither NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType can be set.

  • If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

  • MaxCapacity and NumberOfWorkers must both be at least 1.

MLTransformNotReadyException.documentation: The machine learning transform is not ready to run.

Node.documentation: A node represents an AWS Glue component like Trigger, Job etc. which is part of a workflow.

CrawlerDetails.documentation: Details of the crawler when the node represents a crawler.

JobDetails.documentation: Details of the Job when the node represents a Job.

Name.documentation: The name of the AWS Glue component represented by the node.

TriggerDetails.documentation: Details of the Trigger when the node represents a Trigger.

Type.documentation: The type of AWS Glue component represented by the node.

UniqueId.documentation: The unique Id assigned to the node within the workflow.

NotifyDelayAfter.documentation: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

Order.documentation: Specifies the sort order of a sorted column.

SortOrder.documentation: Indicates that the column is sorted in ascending order (== 1), or in descending order (==0).

CreationTime.documentation: The time at which the partition was created.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which to create the partition.

LastAccessTime.documentation: The last time at which the partition was accessed.

LastAnalyzedTime.documentation: The last time at which column statistics were computed for this partition.

StorageDescriptor.documentation: Provides information about the physical location where the partition is stored.

TableName.documentation: The name of the database table in which to create the partition.

PartitionInput.documentation: The structure used to create and update a partition.

LastAccessTime.documentation: The last time at which the partition was accessed.

LastAnalyzedTime.documentation: The last time at which column statistics were computed for this partition.

StorageDescriptor.documentation: Provides information about the physical location where the partition is stored.

Values.documentation:
The values of the partition. Although this parameter is not required by the SDK, you must specify this parameter for a valid input.

The values for the keys for the new partition must be passed as an array of String objects that must be ordered in the same order as the partition keys appearing in the Amazon S3 prefix. Otherwise AWS Glue will add the values to the wrong keys.

PartitionValueList.documentation: Contains a list of values defining partitions.

PhysicalConnectionRequirements.documentation: Specifies the physical requirements for a connection.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The connection's Availability Zone. This field is redundant because the specified subnet implies the Availability Zone to be used. Currently the field must be populated, but it will be deprecated in the future.

SecurityGroupIdList.documentation: The security group ID list used by the connection.

SubnetId.documentation: The subnet ID used by the connection.

Predecessor.documentation: A job run that was used in the predicate of a conditional trigger that triggered this job run.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job definition used by the predecessor job run.

RunId.documentation: The job-run ID of the predecessor job run.

Predicate.documentation: Defines the predicate of the trigger, which determines when it fires.

Conditions.documentation: A list of the conditions that determine when the trigger will fire.

Logical.documentation: An optional field if only one condition is listed. If multiple conditions are listed, then this field is required.

Permissions.documentation: The permissions that are granted to the principal.

Comparator.documentation: The comparator used to compare this property to others.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog to set the security configuration for. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

PolicyExistsCondition.documentation: A value of MUST_EXIST is used to update a policy. A value of NOT_EXIST is used to create a new policy. If a value of NONE or a null value is used, the call will not depend on the existence of a policy.

PolicyHashCondition.documentation: The hash value returned when the previous policy was set using PutResourcePolicy. Its purpose is to prevent concurrent modifications of a policy. Do not use this parameter if no previous policy has been set.

PolicyInJson.documentation: Contains the policy document to set, in JSON format.

PolicyHash.documentation: A hash of the policy that has just been set. This must be included in a subsequent call that overwrites or updates this policy.

Name.documentation: Name of the workflow which was run.

RunId.documentation: The ID of the workflow run for which the run properties should be updated.

RunProperties.documentation: The properties to put for the specified run.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job in question.

RunId.documentation: The unique run identifier associated with this job run.

S3Encryption.documentation: Specifies how Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) data should be encrypted.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the KMS key to be used to encrypt the data.

S3EncryptionMode.documentation: The encryption mode to use for Amazon S3 data.

S3Target.documentation: Specifies a data store in Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3).

Exclusions.documentation: A list of glob patterns used to exclude from the crawl. For more information, see Catalog Tables with a Crawler.

Path.documentation: The path to the Amazon S3 target.

Schedule.documentation: A scheduling object using a cron statement to schedule an event.

ScheduleExpression.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule. For more information, see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, specify cron(15 12 * * ? *).

SchemaChangePolicy.documentation: A policy that specifies update and deletion behaviors for the crawler.

DeleteBehavior.documentation: The deletion behavior when the crawler finds a deleted object.

UpdateBehavior.documentation: The update behavior when the crawler finds a changed schema.

SchemaColumn.documentation: A key-value pair representing a column and data type that this transform can run against. The Schema parameter of the MLTransform may contain up to 100 of these structures.

DataType.documentation: The type of data in the column.

Name.documentation: The name of the column.

CatalogId.documentation: A unique identifier, consisting of account_id/datalake.

Filters.documentation: A list of key-value pairs, and a comparator used to filter the search results. Returns all entities matching the predicate.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of tables to return in a single response.

NextToken.documentation: A continuation token, included if this is a continuation call.

SearchText.documentation:
A string used for a text search.

Specifying a value in quotes filters based on an exact match to the value.

SortCriteria.documentation: A list of criteria for sorting the results by a field name, in an ascending or descending order.

NextToken.documentation: A continuation token, present if the current list segment is not the last.

TableList.documentation: A list of the requested Table objects. The SearchTables response returns only the tables that you have access to.

CreatedTimeStamp.documentation: The time at which this security configuration was created.

EncryptionConfiguration.documentation: The encryption configuration associated with this security configuration.

Name.documentation: The name of the security configuration.

Segment.documentation: Defines a non-overlapping region of a table's partitions, allowing multiple requests to be executed in parallel.

SegmentNumber.documentation: The zero-based index number of the segment. For example, if the total number of segments is 4, SegmentNumber values range from 0 through 3.

SerDeInfo.documentation: Information about a serialization/deserialization program (SerDe) that serves as an extractor and loader.

Name.documentation: Name of the SerDe.

Parameters.documentation: These key-value pairs define initialization parameters for the SerDe.

SerializationLibrary.documentation: Usually the class that implements the SerDe. An example is org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.columnar.ColumnarSerDe.

SkewedInfo.documentation: Specifies skewed values in a table. Skewed values are those that occur with very high frequency.

SkewedColumnNames.documentation: A list of names of columns that contain skewed values.

SkewedColumnValueLocationMaps.documentation: A mapping of skewed values to the columns that contain them.

SkewedColumnValues.documentation: A list of values that appear so frequently as to be considered skewed.

SortCriterion.documentation: Specifies a field to sort by and a sort order.

FieldName.documentation: The name of the field on which to sort.

Name.documentation: Name of the crawler to start.

OutputS3Path.documentation: The Amazon S3 path where you export the labels.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the machine learning transform.

TaskRunId.documentation: The unique identifier for the task run.

InputS3Path.documentation: The Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path from where you import the labels.

ReplaceAllLabels.documentation: Indicates whether to overwrite your existing labels.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the machine learning transform.

TaskRunId.documentation: The unique identifier for the task run.

JobRunId.documentation: The ID assigned to this job run.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the machine learning transform.

TaskRunId.documentation: The unique identifier associated with this run.

OutputS3Path.documentation: The Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path where you generate the labeling set.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the machine learning transform.

TaskRunId.documentation: The unique run identifier that is associated with this task run.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger to start.
The name of the trigger that was started.
The name of the workflow to start.
Name of the crawler to stop.

CrawlerName.documentation: Name of the crawler whose schedule state to set.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger to stop.
The name of the trigger that was stopped.

StorageDescriptor.documentation: Describes the physical storage of table data.

BucketColumns.documentation: A list of reducer grouping columns, clustering columns, and bucketing columns in the table.

Columns.documentation: A list of the Columns in the table.

Compressed.documentation: True if the data in the table is compressed, or False if not.

InputFormat.documentation: The input format: SequenceFileInputFormat (binary), or TextInputFormat, or a custom format.

Location.documentation: The physical location of the table. By default, this takes the form of the warehouse location, followed by the database location in the warehouse, followed by the table name.

NumberOfBuckets.documentation: Must be specified if the table contains any dimension columns.

OutputFormat.documentation: The output format: SequenceFileOutputFormat (binary), or IgnoreKeyTextOutputFormat, or a custom format.

SkewedInfo.documentation: The information about values that appear frequently in a column (skewed values).

SortColumns.documentation: A list specifying the sort order of each bucket in the table.

StoredAsSubDirectories.documentation: True if the table data is stored in subdirectories, or False if not.

Table.documentation: Represents a collection of related data organized in columns and rows.

CreateTime.documentation: The time when the table definition was created in the Data Catalog.

CreatedBy.documentation: The person or entity who created the table.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database where the table metadata resides. For Hive compatibility, this must be all lowercase.

IsRegisteredWithLakeFormation.documentation: Indicates whether the table has been registered with AWS Lake Formation.

LastAccessTime.documentation: The last time that the table was accessed. This is usually taken from HDFS, and might not be reliable.

LastAnalyzedTime.documentation: The last time that column statistics were computed for this table.

Name.documentation: The table name. For Hive compatibility, this must be entirely lowercase.

Parameters.documentation: These key-value pairs define properties associated with the table.

PartitionKeys.documentation:
A list of columns by which the table is partitioned. Only primitive types are supported as partition keys.

When you create a table used by Amazon Athena, and you do not specify any partitionKeys, you must at least set the value of partitionKeys to an empty list. For example:

"PartitionKeys": []

StorageDescriptor.documentation: A storage descriptor containing information about the physical storage of this table.

UpdateTime.documentation: The last time that the table was updated.

ViewExpandedText.documentation: If the table is a view, the expanded text of the view; otherwise null.

ViewOriginalText.documentation: If the table is a view, the original text of the view; otherwise null.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table. For Hive compatibility, this must be entirely lowercase.

TableInput.documentation: A structure used to define a table.

LastAccessTime.documentation: The last time that the table was accessed.

LastAnalyzedTime.documentation: The last time that column statistics were computed for this table.

Name.documentation: The table name. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

Parameters.documentation: These key-value pairs define properties associated with the table.

PartitionKeys.documentation:
A list of columns by which the table is partitioned. Only primitive types are supported as partition keys.

When you create a table used by Amazon Athena, and you do not specify any partitionKeys, you must at least set the value of partitionKeys to an empty list. For example:

"PartitionKeys": []

StorageDescriptor.documentation: A storage descriptor containing information about the physical storage of this table.

ViewExpandedText.documentation: If the table is a view, the expanded text of the view; otherwise null.

ViewOriginalText.documentation: If the table is a view, the original text of the view; otherwise null.

VersionId.documentation: The ID value that identifies this table version. A VersionId is a string representation of an integer. Each version is incremented by 1.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table in question.

VersionId.documentation: The ID value of the version in question. A VersionID is a string representation of an integer. Each version is incremented by 1.

ResourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the AWS Glue resource to which to add the tags. For more information about AWS Glue resource ARNs, see the AWS Glue ARN string pattern.

TaskRun.documentation: The sampling parameters that are associated with the machine learning transform.

CompletedOn.documentation: The last point in time that the requested task run was completed.

ErrorString.documentation: The list of error strings associated with this task run.

ExecutionTime.documentation: The amount of time (in seconds) that the task run consumed resources.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The last point in time that the requested task run was updated.

LogGroupName.documentation: The names of the log group for secure logging, associated with this task run.

Properties.documentation: Specifies configuration properties associated with this task run.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time that this task run started.

Status.documentation: The current status of the requested task run.

TaskRunId.documentation: The unique identifier for this task run.

TaskRunFilterCriteria.documentation: The criteria that are used to filter the task runs for the machine learning transform.

StartedAfter.documentation: Filter on task runs started after this date.

StartedBefore.documentation: Filter on task runs started before this date.

Status.documentation: The current status of the task run.

TaskRunProperties.documentation: The configuration properties for the task run.

ExportLabelsTaskRunProperties.documentation: The configuration properties for an exporting labels task run.

FindMatchesTaskRunProperties.documentation: The configuration properties for a find matches task run.

ImportLabelsTaskRunProperties.documentation: The configuration properties for an importing labels task run.

LabelingSetGenerationTaskRunProperties.documentation: The configuration properties for a labeling set generation task run.

TaskRunSortCriteria.documentation: The sorting criteria that are used to sort the list of task runs for the machine learning transform.

Column.documentation: The column to be used to sort the list of task runs for the machine learning transform.

SortDirection.documentation: The sort direction to be used to sort the list of task runs for the machine learning transform.

TransformFilterCriteria.documentation: The criteria used to filter the machine learning transforms.

CreatedAfter.documentation: The time and date after which the transforms were created.

CreatedBefore.documentation: The time and date before which the transforms were created.

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of AWS Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see AWS Glue Versions in the developer guide.

LastModifiedAfter.documentation: Filter on transforms last modified after this date.

LastModifiedBefore.documentation: Filter on transforms last modified before this date.

Name.documentation: A unique transform name that is used to filter the machine learning transforms.

Schema.documentation: Filters on datasets with a specific schema. The Map<Column, Type> object is an array of key-value pairs representing the schema this transform accepts, where Column is the name of a column, and Type is the type of the data such as an integer or string. Has an upper bound of 100 columns.

Status.documentation: Filters the list of machine learning transforms by the last known status of the transforms (to indicate whether a transform can be used or not). One of "NOT_READY", "READY", or "DELETING".

TransformType.documentation: The type of machine learning transform that is used to filter the machine learning transforms.

TransformParameters.documentation: The algorithm-specific parameters that are associated with the machine learning transform.

FindMatchesParameters.documentation: The parameters for the find matches algorithm.

TransformType.documentation:
The type of machine learning transform.

For information about the types of machine learning transforms, see Creating Machine Learning Transforms.

TransformSortCriteria.documentation: The sorting criteria that are associated with the machine learning transform.

Column.documentation: The column to be used in the sorting criteria that are associated with the machine learning transform.

SortDirection.documentation: The sort direction to be used in the sorting criteria that are associated with the machine learning transform.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger.

Predicate.documentation: The predicate of this trigger, which defines when it will fire.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

Type.documentation: The type of trigger that this is.

WorkflowName.documentation: The name of the workflow associated with the trigger.

TriggerNodeDetails.documentation: The details of a Trigger node present in the workflow.

Trigger.documentation: The information of the trigger represented by the trigger node.

TriggerUpdate.documentation: A structure used to provide information used to update a trigger. This object updates the previous trigger definition by overwriting it completely.

Name.documentation: Reserved for future use.

Predicate.documentation: The predicate of this trigger, which defines when it will fire.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

ResourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource from which to remove the tags.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connection resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

ConnectionInput.documentation: A ConnectionInput object that redefines the connection in question.

Name.documentation: The name of the connection definition to update.

Classifiers.documentation: A list of custom classifiers that the user has registered. By default, all built-in classifiers are included in a crawl, but these custom classifiers always override the default classifiers for a given classification.

Configuration.documentation: The crawler configuration information. This versioned JSON string allows users to specify aspects of a crawler's behavior. For more information, see Configuring a Crawler.

CrawlerSecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used by this crawler.

DatabaseName.documentation: The AWS Glue database where results are stored, such as: arn:aws:daylight:us-east-1::database/sometable/*.

Name.documentation: Name of the new crawler.

Role.documentation: The IAM role or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM role that is used by the new crawler to access customer resources.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule. For more information, see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, specify cron(15 12 * * ? *).

SchemaChangePolicy.documentation: The policy for the crawler's update and deletion behavior.

TablePrefix.documentation: The table prefix used for catalog tables that are created.

CrawlerName.documentation: The name of the crawler whose schedule to update.

Schedule.documentation: The updated cron expression used to specify the schedule. For more information, see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, specify cron(15 12 * * ? *).

UpdateCsvClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a custom CSV classifier to be updated.

AllowSingleColumn.documentation: Enables the processing of files that contain only one column.

ContainsHeader.documentation: Indicates whether the CSV file contains a header.

Delimiter.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what separates each column entry in the row.

DisableValueTrimming.documentation: Specifies not to trim values before identifying the type of column values. The default value is true.

Header.documentation: A list of strings representing column names.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

QuoteSymbol.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what combines content into a single column value. It must be different from the column delimiter.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the metadata database resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseInput.documentation: A DatabaseInput object specifying the new definition of the metadata database in the catalog.

Name.documentation: The name of the database to update in the catalog. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase.

AddArguments.documentation:
The map of arguments to add the map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

Valid arguments are:

  • "--enable-glue-datacatalog": ""

  • "GLUE_PYTHON_VERSION": "3"

  • "GLUE_PYTHON_VERSION": "2"

You can specify a version of Python support for development endpoints by using the Arguments parameter in the CreateDevEndpoint or UpdateDevEndpoint APIs. If no arguments are provided, the version defaults to Python 2.

AddPublicKeys.documentation: The list of public keys for the DevEndpoint to use.

CustomLibraries.documentation: Custom Python or Java libraries to be loaded in the DevEndpoint.

DeleteArguments.documentation: The list of argument keys to be deleted from the map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

DeletePublicKeys.documentation: The list of public keys to be deleted from the DevEndpoint.

EndpointName.documentation: The name of the DevEndpoint to be updated.

PublicKey.documentation: The public key for the DevEndpoint to use.

UpdateEtlLibraries.documentation: True if the list of custom libraries to be loaded in the development endpoint needs to be updated, or False if otherwise.

UpdateGrokClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a grok classifier to update when passed to UpdateClassifier.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches, such as Twitter, JSON, Omniture logs, Amazon CloudWatch Logs, and so on.

CustomPatterns.documentation: Optional custom grok patterns used by this classifier.

GrokPattern.documentation: The grok pattern used by this classifier.

Name.documentation: The name of the GrokClassifier.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job definition to update.

JobUpdate.documentation: Specifies the values with which to update the job definition.

JobName.documentation: Returns the name of the updated job definition.

UpdateJsonClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a JSON classifier to be updated.

JsonPath.documentation: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. AWS Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

Description.documentation: A description of the transform. The default is an empty string.

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of AWS Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see AWS Glue Versions in the developer guide.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry a task for this transform after a task run fails.

Name.documentation: The unique name that you gave the transform when you created it.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation: The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when this task runs.

Parameters.documentation: The configuration parameters that are specific to the transform type (algorithm) used. Conditionally dependent on the transform type.

Role.documentation: The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions.

Timeout.documentation: The timeout for a task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

TransformId.documentation: A unique identifier that was generated when the transform was created.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when this task runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier for the transform that was updated.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partition to be updated resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the table in question resides.

PartitionInput.documentation: The new partition object to update the partition to.

PartitionValueList.documentation: A list of the values defining the partition.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table in which the partition to be updated is located.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the table resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the table resides. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

SkipArchive.documentation: By default, UpdateTable always creates an archived version of the table before updating it. However, if skipArchive is set to true, UpdateTable does not create the archived version.

TableInput.documentation: An updated TableInput object to define the metadata table in the catalog.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger to update.

TriggerUpdate.documentation: The new values with which to update the trigger.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the function to be updated is located. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database where the function to be updated is located.

FunctionInput.documentation: A FunctionInput object that redefines the function in the Data Catalog.

DefaultRunProperties.documentation: A collection of properties to be used as part of each execution of the workflow.

Name.documentation: Name of the workflow to be updated.
The name of the workflow which was specified in input.

UpdateXMLClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies an XML classifier to be updated.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

RowTag.documentation: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. This cannot identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

UserDefinedFunction.documentation: Represents the equivalent of a Hive user-defined function (UDF) definition.

ClassName.documentation: The Java class that contains the function code.

CreateTime.documentation: The time at which the function was created.

UserDefinedFunctionInput.documentation: A structure used to create or update a user-defined function.

ClassName.documentation: The Java class that contains the function code.

Workflow.documentation: A workflow represents a flow in which AWS Glue components should be executed to complete a logical task.

CreatedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow was created.

DefaultRunProperties.documentation: A collection of properties to be used as part of each execution of the workflow.

Graph.documentation: The graph representing all the AWS Glue components that belong to the workflow as nodes and directed connections between them as edges.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow was last modified.

LastRun.documentation: The information about the last execution of the workflow.

Name.documentation: The name of the workflow representing the flow.

WorkflowGraph.documentation: A workflow graph represents the complete workflow containing all the AWS Glue components present in the workflow and all the directed connections between them.

Edges.documentation: A list of all the directed connections between the nodes belonging to the workflow.

Nodes.documentation: A list of the the AWS Glue components belong to the workflow represented as nodes.

WorkflowRun.documentation: A workflow run is an execution of a workflow providing all the runtime information.

CompletedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow run completed.

Graph.documentation: The graph representing all the AWS Glue components that belong to the workflow as nodes and directed connections between them as edges.

Name.documentation: Name of the workflow which was executed.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow run was started.

WorkflowRunProperties.documentation: The workflow run properties which were set during the run.

WorkflowRunStatistics.documentation: Workflow run statistics provides statistics about the workflow run.

FailedActions.documentation: Total number of Actions which have failed.

StoppedActions.documentation: Total number of Actions which have stopped.

SucceededActions.documentation: Total number of Actions which have succeeded.

TimeoutActions.documentation: Total number of Actions which timed out.

TotalActions.documentation: Total number of Actions in the workflow run.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that this classifier was registered.

LastUpdated.documentation: The time that this classifier was last updated.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

RowTag.documentation: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. This can't identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).
